Authors:
Baharul Islam Choudhury, Mohammed Latif Khan, Selvadurai
Dayanandan
Title:
Genetic relatedness among traditionally cultivated rice
ecotypes in the Eastern Himalayan region based on nucleotide sequences
of the Waxy gene
Keywords:
Boro, Ecotype, Genetic relatedness, Indigenous rice
varieties, Jum, Sali
Abstract:
Indigenous rice varieties in the Eastern Himalayan (EH)
region of Northeast (NE) India are traditionally classified into
different ecotypes namely sali, boro and jum based on the season or type
of cultivation. This study aims to infer the genetic relatedness among
rice ecotypes in NE India based on DNA sequences of Waxy (Wx) gene.
Bayesian, Maximum Parsimony and Neighbor Joining clustering methods
resulted in two distinct groups of varieties among different rice
ecotypes from NE India with similar tree topologies and high statistical
support. The major groups in Bayesian phylogram are supported by more
than 80 percent posterior probability values. The larger group comprised
mostly sali and boro ecotypes along with all agronomically improved
varieties. The smaller group consisted of only traditional varieties,
representing mostly belonging to the jum ecotype, few sali ecotypes and
one boro ecotype. Calculation of fixation index showed very low level of
differentiation between sali and boro (FST = 0.005), moderate
differentiation between sali and jum (FST = 0.108) and high
differentiation between jum and boro (FST = 0.230) ecotypes. The
assessment of genetic relatedness through different analyses showed the
polyphyletic nature of sali, boro and jum ecotypes. It was further
revealed that the classification based on morphology or cultivation type
may not necessarily correspond to their genotype. The unique group
consisting of only indigenous varieties could be used for choosing
varieties for breeding to improve genetic gain through heterosis or to
maintain broader genetic diversity in breeding programs.
